s.text: While Steely Dan and Frank Zappa strike me as tributaries pretty distant from the mainstream Miller was trying to trace, I think you're correctly suspicious of disco's absence--and not just as a high-point of decadence.

While Steely Dan and Frank Zappa strike me as tributaries pretty distant from the mainstream Miller was trying to trace, I think you're correctly suspicious of disco's absence--and not just as a high-point of decadence.

While Steely Dan and Frank Zappa strike me as tributaries pretty distant from the mainstream Miller was trying to trace, I think you're correctly suspicious of disco's absence--and not just as a high-point of decadence.

Disco prefigured the most cataclysmic reordering of rock sound and attitude in 20 years: hip-hop, a form in which the technical "gimmickry" that Miller seems to both enjoy and distrust became central to music-making.
Show me someone like Marilyn Manson and I'll say, OK, Miller's right: Rock is a "finished cultural form--a more or less fixed repertoire of sounds and styles and patterns of behavior."

But show me someone like the Wu-Tang Clan--whom Miller groups with Manson as "musically crude, gleefully obscene, and just plain silly" (as well as "the triumph of the psychopathic adolescent")--and I think Miller's simply not listening.

But show me someone like the Wu-Tang Clan--whom Miller groups with Manson as "musically crude, gleefully obscene, and just plain silly" (as well as "the triumph of the psychopathic adolescent")--and I think Miller's simply not listening.
I certainly don't need to hear this fetishized event described again, and I respect his choice of Altamont as the more relevant chapter in rock's dark lineage.

Earlier in the book, he describes the global impact of Sgt. Pepper --when you could hear it wafting out of cars and cafes "from Los Angeles to London, from Paris to Madrid"--with the wistfulness of an old Catholic rhapsodizing the Latin mass.
